questions.text: A 35 year female presents with history of fall on outstretched hand while going to kitchen and pain in left shoulder region. Xray shows greater tuberosity and surgical neck humerus fracture. Which classification system can be used for better plan of management ?
questions.solution:
Proximal humeral fracture follows Neer classification.


It is important to properly evaluate these fractures by AP and axial X-rays. Neer has classified these fractures into 4 types depending upon the construction of the fracture. He identified 4 parts in the upper end of the humerus - shaft, head, greater tuberosity and lesser tuberosity. Depending upon in how many parts the bone has fractured, he divided them into one to four part fracture. For example, a fracture where the head and the greater tuberosity have fractures and separated from the shaft, it will be called a three-part fracture. This classification helps in deciding the treatment and prognosis.


  • Salter Harris fracture classification is for pediatric traumatic fractures. (Option C)
  • Frykmann's fracture classification is for distal end radius fracture in adults (Option A)
  • Pauwel's classification is for neck femur fracture in adults. (Option D)

Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 92

choices.text: Anterior dislocation is the most common joint dislocation overall
Recurrence is the most common complication of an anterior shoulder dislocation
Bankart's lesion can be managed by remplissage procedure
Hill- Sach's defect occurs in postero-lateral quadrant of humeral head

questions.text: A 23 year old young football player sustained injury to left shoulder and was diagnosed to have traumatic anterior dislocation of shoulder joint which was reduced in emergency room. Following that he had multiple episodes of dislocations. Select the false statement.
questions.solution:
Shoulder is the commonest joint in the human body to dislocate. It occurs more commonly in adults, and is rare in children. Anterior dislocation is much more common than posterior dislocation(Option A). The shoulder is the commonest joint to undergo recurrent dislocation(Option B).

Bankart's lesion: Recurrent dislocations causes stripping of the glenoidal labrum along with the periosteum from the antero-inferior surface of the glenoid and scapular neck.

Bankart's operation: The glenoid labrum and capsule are re-attached to the front of the glenoid rim. This is a technically demanding procedure, but has become simpler with the use of special fixation devices called anchors. Bony bankart requires a surgery called as Latarjet procedure.

Hill-Sachs lesion: This is a depression on the humeral head in its postero-lateral quadrant(Option D) caused by impingement by the anterior edge of the glenoid on the head as it dislocates. Remplissage surgery is required to fill in the defect with joint capsule and make the defect extra-articular.


MNEMONIC -

T- Traumatic anterior dislocation

U- Unilateral

B- Bankart's lesion (ant-inf labrum)

H- Hill-sach's lesion (post-lateral head)

S- Surgery is mandatory

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 90.

questions.text: Fracture through the neck of 5th metacarpal is known as?
questions.solution:
A boxer's fracture is a break in the neck of the fifth metacarpal bone, which is located just below the knuckle of the little finger. It commonly occurs due to punching a hard object with a closed fist. Symptoms include pain, swelling, bruising, and sometimes deformity in the affected area. Treatment typically involves immobilization with a splint or cast, though severe cases may require surgery. Healing time is usually 4-6 weeks.


Fig. Boxer fracture

Option D - Smith's fracture: A fracture occurring in adults, at the cortico-cancellous junction of the distal end of the radius with ventral tilt and other displacements (reverse of Colles').


Option A - Pott's fracture: Bi-malleolar ankle fracture.


Option C - Dancer's fracture - Oblique/ spiral fracture of the 5th metatarsal shaft extending in distal lateral to proximal medial direction.


Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number:3

Reference: Rockwood and Green's Fractures in Adult's 9th edition, page number. 4833

questions.text: A 70 yr old gentleman sustained trivial fall on outstretched hand at home and injured his right wrist. On examination there is a diner fork deformity. Xray right wrist AP and lateral views shows classical Colle's fracture. All of the following displacements can be seen on the x-ray except?
questions.solution:
In Colles' fracture the fracture line runs transversely at the cortico-cancellous junction. In the majority of cases, one or more of the displacements described below occur; although in a few cases it may be a crack fracture without displacement. The following are the displacements seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Impaction of fragments (Option D)
  • Dorsal displacement (shift)
  • Dorsal tilt (Option C)
  • Lateral (radial) displacement (shift) (Option A)
  • Lateral (radial) tilt
  • Supination

As the displacement occurs, some amount of comminution of the dorsal and lateral cortices, and that of the soft cancellous bone of the distal fragment occurs. Rarely, the whole of the distal fragment is broken into pieces.

Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 112

questions.text: A 45 yr old women who sustained fall on outstretched hand while going down the stairs was diagnosed to have distal radius fracture on xray. The fracture is displaced and unstable and hence needs surgical fixation. All these implants can be used for the same except?
questions.solution:
Nails are implants that are used for intra-medullary fixation of fractures of the shaft (diaphysis) of long bones like femur, tibia, fibula, humerus , radius and ulna. K-nail (Kuntschner's nail) was specifically used for femur shaft fractures in the past. It is not commonly used these days due to availability of better nails for the same.

Fig. K Nail


Distal radius fractures are fractures typically seen in the metaphyseal region or even distal to that towards the wrist joint (intra-articular fractures).

  • These fractures are sometimes transfixed percutaneously using two or more K-wires which are incorporated in the plaster cast. These are used for minimally displaced fractures with good bone quality.(Option C)

Fig. K-Wire(Both ends pointed)


  • In some centres, an external fixator is used to keep the fracture 'distracted', so that the stretched ligaments and periosteum keep the comminuted fragments in place (ligamentotaxis). It is used for highly comminuted fractures or fractures with poor soft tissue coverage/open fractures.(Option B)
  • A more recent addition to the surgical treatment is to fix these fractures with LCP (Locking compression plate). This is the most commonly used modality these days and gives good results post op.(Option A)

Fig. LCP


Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 113

questions.text: Avascular necrosis is a common complication in some bones post fractures due to precarious blood supply. All these fractures are prone to undergo AVN except?
questions.solution:
Common complications of SCH fractures are as follows:

COMPLICATIONS

The supracondylar fracture is notorious for a number of serious complications. These can be:

(i) Immediate - occurring at the time of fracture;

(ii) Early - occurring within first 2-3 days;

(iii) Late - occurring weeks to months after the fracture.

Immediate Complications

  1. Injury to the brachial artery: This is a complication commonly associated with a displaced supracondylar fracture. The brachial artery is usually injured by the sharp edge of the proximal fragment. The damage may vary from just a pressure on the artery to complete disruption. The affects of arterial occlusion at the elbow differ from case to case. Most often, enough blood gets through the collaterals around the elbow to keep the hand alive, but flexor muscles of the forearm may suffer ischaemic damage leading to Volkmann's ischaemia. At times, the vascular compromise may be severe enough to result in gangrene.
  2. Injury to nerves: The median nerve is the most commonly injured nerve. Radial nerve is also sometimes affected. Spontaneous recovery occurs in most cases.

Early Complications

  1. Volkmann's ischaemia: This is an ischaemic injury to the muscles and nerves of the flexor compartment of the forearm. It is caused due to occlusion of the brachial artery by a supracondylar fracture.

Late Complications

  1. Malunion: It is the commonest complication of a supracondylar fracture and results in a cubitus varus deformity. This is because the fracture unites with the distal fragment tilted medially and in internal rotation. Malunion may occur either because of failure to achieve good reduction, or displacement of the fracture within the plaster. The cubitus varus deformity is often termed the Gun stock deformity (Fig-14.11). Sometimes, the distal fragment unites with an excessive backward tilt, resulting in hyperextension at the elbow along with limitation of flexion - basically a change in the arc of movement at the elbow.
  2. Myositis ossificans: This is an ectopic new bone formation around the elbow joint, resulting in stiffness. Massage following the injury, so commonly resorted to in some places, is a major factor responsible for it.
  3. Volkmann's ischaemic contracture (VIC): This is a sequel of Volkmann's ischaemia. The ischaemic muscles are gradually replaced by fibrous tissue, which contracts and draws the wrist and fingers into flexion (Fig-14.12a). If the peripheral nerves are also affected, there will be sensory loss and motor paralysis in the forearm and hand.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 100

questions.text: Choose the correct treatment plan for the x-ray shown in the given image which belongs to an elderly patient of 68 years.
questions.solution:
The given xray shows neck of femur fracture on right side.

Internal fixation: Any of the following implants may be used for internal fixation of neck femur fracture:

  • Multiple cancellous screws (Option D)- most commonly used.
  • Dynamic hip screw (DHS) (Option A) - used sometimes.
  • Multiple Knowle's pins/Moore's pins used in children.

Fixation is usually preferred for patients <60 years of age.

Following is the algorithm for NOF fracture management:


Option B - Hemiarthroplasty - This is a procedure used for elderly (>60 years) patients. In this, the head of the femur is excised and replaced by a prosthesis. There are two types of prosthesis commonly in use: unipolar and bipolar.


Option C - Proximal femoral nail is used for inter-trochanteric and sub-trochanteric femur fracture.

Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 136, 139

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for bone formation in patients with non-union?
questions.solution:
Newer Nonsurgical Methods for Treating Delayed and Nonunion Fractures

The following are newer nonsurgical approaches for treating delayed healing and nonunion fractures:

  • Low-Intensity Pulsed Ultrasound
  • Electromagnetic Stimulation
  • Osteoinductive Bone Morphogenic Proteins (BMPs) - Option D

Bone Morphogenic Proteins (BMPs)

Bone morphogenic proteins, particularly BMP-2, BMP-4, BMP-7, and BMP-9, are osteogenic and induce the formation of both bone and cartilage. They stimulate mesenchymal progenitor cells to promote bone growth.

  • Combination Therapies: Research has explored combining BMP-7 with demineralized bone matrix and processed allograft chips to enhance bone regeneration.
  • Animal Studies: The combination of BMP-2 and BMP-14 has shown promising results in animal models.
  • Genetic Approaches: Advances in genetic engineering now allow for the creation of cells that can secrete the desired proteins at the injury site. This can be achieved by:
    • Direct Gene Delivery: Introducing gene constructs directly to the affected area, where surrounding cells take up the constructs and begin synthesizing the osteoinductive proteins.
    • Ex Vivo Gene Transduction: Transducing cells outside the body and then transplanting these genetically modified cells to the target site.

Option C - PMMA is the polymer of bone cement used in various surgeries.

Option A and B - These have no role in bone formation.

Reference. Practical Orthopaedic Examination made easy by Manish Kumar Varshney 2nd edition page number. 456.

questions.text:
Following a RTA, a patient develops Type IIIa compound tibial fracture, arrange the external fixators in terms of stability (lowest to highest) to be used for management.

1. Ilizarov
2. Uniplanar with single rod
3. Uniplanar with double rod
4. Biplanar
questions.solution:
Ilizarov has highest stability as it provides 360 degree support

Biplanar has higher stability than uniplanar(Double rod > Single rod)



Fig. Ilizarov ring fixator

Sequence of stability from highest to lowest ilizarov>biplanar > Uniplanar with double rod> Uniplanar with single rod.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 7th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 19.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a tibia fracture on cast presents to emergency department with complaints of intense pain. Cast was removed and on examination passive flexion was painful, dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are present and loss of sensation over the first web space was noted. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Compartment Syndrome Management

Based on the clinical history, the patient is likely suffering from compartment syndrome. To confirm this diagnosis, anterior compartment pressure measurement should be performed.

Immediate Intervention

Given the patient's clinical symptoms and signs of leg compartment syndrome, the following steps should be taken without delay:

  • Immediate fasciotomies of all four leg compartments.
  • Fracture stabilization using external fixation.

Tibial Fractures and Compartment Syndrome

Tibial fractures are one of the most common causes of compartment syndrome in the leg. Accurate clinical assessment is crucial for diagnosing acute compartment syndrome. If there is any doubt, intracompartmental pressure measurement can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

The 5 P's of Compartment Syndrome

Key clinical signs of compartment syndrome include:

  • Pain out of proportion to the exam
  • Paralysis
  • Paresthesias (abnormal sensations)
  • Pallor (paleness)
  • Pulselessness

Contraindication to Intramedullary Nailing or ORIF

In this case, intramedullary nailing or open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) should not be performed, as surgery itself can predispose the patient to developing compartment syndrome.

Delta P in Compartment Syndrome

  • Delta P is calculated as diastolic blood pressure minus intracompartmental pressure.
  • If delta P is less than 30 mm Hg, the patient requires immediate fasciotomy to relieve compartment syndrome.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 47

questions.text:
Following a femur shaft fracture in a young patient with head injury, the consultant asked the orthopaedic resident to provide tibial skeletal traction. Which of the following instruments will the resident request from the nurse to do the same?

1. Thomas splint
2. K-wire
3. Steinman's pin
4. Denham's pin
5. Bohler's stirrup
6. Bohler brown splint / Frame
questions.solution:
Skeletal Traction

Skeletal traction involves applying traction directly to the bone by inserting a K-wire or Steinmann pin through the bone. This method provides direct and stable traction for managing fractures.

Steinmann Pin

The Steinmann pin is a sturdy, straight steel rod with a diameter ranging from 3 to 6 mm. It is primarily used for skeletal traction, with common insertion sites including:

  • The upper end of the tibia
  • The supracondylar region of the femur
  • The calcaneum

Fig. Bohler stirrup and Steinmann pin for skeletal traction


Böhler's Stirrup

The Böhler's stirrup is a device designed to hold a Steinmann pin in place and apply traction. The screws on the sides of the stirrup secure the pin, and it allows the direction of traction to be adjusted without moving the pin inside the bone, thereby preventing pin loosening.

Fig. Bohler Stirrup


Böhler-Braun Splint

The Böhler-Braun splint is a traction frame equipped with multiple pulleys (1-3) that guide the traction cord for various fracture treatments.

Key features:

  • Convenience: More user-friendly than a Thomas splint as it lacks a ring, which is often a source of discomfort, especially for elderly patients.
  • Limitation: It does not have an inbuilt system for countertraction, making it unsuitable for patient transportation.

Fig. Bohler Braun Splint


Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page number. 1215.

questions.text: 8 years old boy sustained fracture lateral condyle of humerus, gradually developed elbow deformity, which of the following are the likely outcomes?
questions.solution:
Lateral Condyle Humerus Fracture Nonunion and Its Complications

A lateral condyle humerus fracture nonunion can lead to these significant complications:

  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy
  • Non-union leading to Cubitus valgus deformity

Tardy Ulnar Nerve Palsy

The patient is experiencing tardy ulnar nerve palsy, which commonly develops after a lateral condyle humerus fracture nonunion. This condition is often the result of cubitus valgus deformity, which stretches the ulnar nerve over time, leading to ulnar nerve palsy (Option D - Loss of finger adduction).

  • Typical Cause: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is frequently a consequence of nonunion following a lateral condyle fracture in childhood, which results in cubitus valgus deformity. The deformity progressively causes stretching of the ulnar nerve.

Diagnosis and Management of Nonunion

A lateral condyle fracture is considered to be in nonunion if it shows no signs of healing after 3 months.

  • Early Presentation of Nonunion: Patients often present with pain and instability in the affected area.
    • Treatment: Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with bone grafting is recommended.
  • Late Presentation of Nonunion: In late cases, patients may develop a painless mass or cubitus valgus deformity (Figs. 2.49A and B). As the valgus deformity worsens, the ulnar nerve can become stretched, leading to tardy ulnar nerve palsy.

Treatment for Severe Cases

In severe cases of cubitus valgus deformity with tardy ulnar nerve palsy, the following treatments are considered:

  • Corrective osteotomy (e.g., Milch osteotomy)
  • Ulnar nerve transposition (may be performed with or without osteotomy, depending on the severity of nerve involvement).

Option A, B and C - All these are signs of median nerve palsy. Median nerve palsy is not a known complication of lateral condyle humerus fractures.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page number. 1508

questions.text: Fracture at which site in leg will cause failure of dorsiflexion of foot ?
questions.solution:
Common Peroneal Nerve Injury and Foot Drop

Injury to the common peroneal nerve at the fibular neck commonly leads to foot drop. This nerve is more frequently affected than the tibial nerve, and its vulnerability at the fibular neck is due to its relatively fixed position, making it more prone to damage from stretching or trauma.

Anatomy of the Sciatic Nerve

The sciatic nerve is composed of two distinct components:

  • Tibial nerve
  • Common peroneal nerve

Injuries to the common peroneal nerve are more common than tibial nerve injuries, even in cases of sciatic nerve involvement. Complete lesions of the sciatic nerve are rare.

Mechanism of Injury

Nerves are relatively fixed at certain points along their course, making them less tolerant to stretching. The common peroneal nerve is particularly vulnerable where it passes over the neck of the fibula. Stretching of the sciatic nerve often results in isolated damage to the common peroneal nerve, which affects the function of the foot.

Clinical Presentation

  • Foot drop: This occurs due to the weakness of the dorsiflexors of the foot, leaving the foot in a plantar flexed position.
  • High-step gait: Patients with foot drop often present with a characteristic 'high-step gait', where they need to lift their foot higher than normal to clear the ground while walking.
  • Muscle paralysis: The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot, and paralysis of these muscles results in foot drop.
  • Plantar flexors: The plantar flexors of the foot remain unaffected, as they are supplied by the tibial nerve.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number:62, 69.

questions.text: A 23 year man in a road traffic accident sustained head injury along with closed femur shaft fracture. He was brought to the hospital next day by his relatives as he developed breathlessness, confusion and skin rashes. Choose correct option in this regard
questions.solution:
Fat Embolism

Fat embolism is a serious complication that typically presents 12-48 hours after a femur fracture or polytrauma. Improper handling, such as frequent shifting of the patient without proper fracture splintage, should be avoided to prevent fat embolism.

Pathophysiology

The essential feature of fat embolism is the occlusion of small blood vessels by fat globules, which can occur via two main mechanisms:

  1. Release of free fatty acids: Lipases act on neutral fat, releasing free fatty acids that induce toxic vasculitis, leading to platelet-fibrin thrombosis.
  2. Obstruction of small pulmonary vessels: Fat globules physically block small blood vessels in the lungs.

Consequences

  1. Cerebral Type:
    • Symptoms: Drowsiness, restlessness, disorientation, and gradual progression to coma.
  2. Pulmonary Type:
    • Symptoms: Tachypnea (rapid breathing) and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are the prominent features.

Common Features

  • Petechial Rash: A characteristic petechial rash may appear, typically on the front of the neck, anterior axillary folds, chest, or conjunctiva.
  • Respiratory Failure: If untreated, or in severe cases despite treatment, the patient may develop respiratory failure, which can lead to death.
  • Following are the components of Gurd's criteria:

Treatment

  • Oxygen support to manage respiratory distress.
  • Low molecular weight (LMW) heparin to prevent thromboembolism.
  • Steroids to reduce inflammation.

Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number:43

questions.text: Which of the following is true about synovial chondromatosis?
questions.solution:
Loose Bodies in the Joint

Loose bodies in the joint are a common issue, most frequently affecting the knee joint. The most common cause is a fractured osteophyte in patients with osteoarthritis. Other causes include:

  • Knee osteochondritis
  • Osteochondral fractures
  • Synovial chondromatosis (where the number of loose bodies can exceed 50-60).

Symptoms

Patients typically report sudden locking of the joint, and in many cases, they can feel the loose body moving within the joint.

Diagnosis

Most loose bodies are radiopaque, meaning they can be identified on plain X-rays. In some cases, arthroscopic examination may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Treatment

The treatment involves removal of the loose body, either through arthroscopy or by surgically opening the joint.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 326
